text: BR17120 Genetics, evolution and Diversity: Eukaryote Protists 1 Jo Hamilton (e-mail: jvh) Objectives and learning outcomes.  Multicellularity.  Eukaryotes acquired featured from Archaea and bacteria.  Many eukaryotes are not animals, plants or fungi.  Origin of modern eukaryote cell.  Major eukaryote lineages diversified in the Precambrian. Major Earth events affected evolution  Continental collisions & volcanic eruptions – affected climate – atmosphere – sea levels.  Meteor strikes – sudden environmental shifts. Origins of single-celled organisms - recap  Early prokaryotes – only inhabitants Earth from ~3.5 to ~ 2.1 bya.  Prokaryotes transformed life on Earth. Maulucioni y Doridí - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=2588869 3 Oxygen  O2-generating cyanobacteria – Enough O2 for metabolic oxidation reactions.  Aerobic prokaryotes – more energy - proliferated.  Increased atmospheric O2 – Evolution large eukaryotic cells – Eventually multicellular organisms. Matthewjparker - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=2411 9069 Diversification of multicellular life  Multicellular life – extensive diversification in Cambrian – Evolutionary radiation.  During Mesozoic distinct terrestrial biotas evolved on each continent.  5 mass extinctions – punctuated history of life in Paleozoic & Mesozoic eras. Smith609 at English Wikipedia, CC BY 2.5, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php ?curid=7049084 Cenozoic era  Cenozoic - divided into Tertiary & Quaternary periods – Subdivided into epochs.  Cenozoic – emergence of modern biota – E.g. radiation of mammals – E.g. dominance of flowering plants. Prof saxx - Own work, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=2846254 Georg Dionysius Ehret - World Picdatabase Gallery 483049, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid =2480980 Eukaryotes acquired features from Archaea & bacteria  Many eukaryotes - not plants, animals or fungi – Traditonally “protists”. – Not a formal taxonomic group. – Umbrella term for non- plant, animal or fungal eukaryotes. Origin of modern eukaryote cell  5 key steps 1. Origin of flexible cell surface. 2. Origin of cytoskeleton. 3. Origin of nuclear envelope enclosing a genome organised into chromosomes. 4. Appearance of digestive vacuoles. 5. Acquisition of certain organelles via endosymbiosis. Chloroplasts transferred among eukaryotes several times  Chloroplasts – engulfment of 1 cyanobacterium by larger eukaryotic cell – primary endosymbiosis  1st photosynthetic eukaryotes.  Primary endosymbiosis gave rise to chloroplasts of red algae, green algae & land plants. Chloroplasts transferred among eukaryotes several times  Almost all other photosynthetic eukaryotes result from additional endosymbiosis events – E.g. Photosynthetic euglenids - chloroplasts from secondary endosymbiosis.  Tertiary endosymbiosis – dinoflagellate lost chloroplast – took up another protist that had acquired chloroplast through secondary endosymbiosis. Major eukaryote lineages diversified in Precambrian  Most eukaryotes classified 1 of 8 major clades: – Alveolates – Stramenopiles – Excavates – Plants – Rhizarians – Amoebozoans – Fungi – Animals  Began to diversify 1.5 billion years ago Protist eukaryotes are very diverse  Diverse body forms & nutritional lifestyles – Some mobile – Photosynthetic or heterotrophs – Unicellular & multicellular protists  Most microscopic – Giant kelps ~45m  Unicellular protists = microbial eukaryotes – But…large multicellular protists exist. Airickson - Own work, CC BY-SA 4.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid= 37101932 Multicellularity  Arose many times in eukaryote evolution – Plants, animals, fungi, brown algae & other multicellular eukaryotes.  Many unicellular species form large colonies.  “Continuum” between fully integrated multicellular spp. & loosely integrated multicellular colonies of cells. Major eukaryote lineages diversified in Precambrian Eukaryote phylogeny. Image from http://tolweb.org/Eukaryotes Alveolates.  Alveolates – Dinoflagellates – Apicomplexans – Ciliates Alveolates  Possess sacs – alveoli - beneath cell membranes – Supports cell surface?  Unicellular  Most photosynthetic  Diverse body forms – 3 groups: Dinoflagellates, apicomplexans & ciliates. Fjouenne - http://planktonnet.awi.de/, CC BY-SA 3.0 nl, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.ph p?curid=5552271 TimVickers at English Wikipedia - Transferred from en.wikipedia to Commons., Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.ph p?curid=2932677 Deuterostome - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.ph p?curid=25530266 Dinoflagellates  Mostly marine & photosynthetic  1O producers  Chloroplasts golden brown colour – photosynthetic & accessory pigments.  Some spp. – cause red tides – are photosynthetic endosymbionts – are parasitic in marine organisms. Dinoflagellates  2 flagella: – 1 in equatorial groove around cell – 2nd passes down longitudinal groove & into surroundings  Some spp. can take on different forms depending on environmental conditions – e.g. amoeboid  Pfiesteria piscicida – >20 forms – controversial – Stun & feed on fish when in great numbers Apicomplexans  All parasitic.  Apical complex – mass organelles apical end cell  Host invasion  Plasmodium spp. – malaria – Mosquito (Anopheles spp.) definitive host  Apical complex aids in invasion of human erythrocytes. Apicomplexans  Complex life cycles: parasite sexual & asexual reproduction.  Definitive & intermediate hosts – E.g. Plasmodium spp. – mosquito & vertebrate host. – E.g. Toxoplasma gondii – cats & rats  Increased risk taking behaviours in rats (& humans!) CC BY 4.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/ind ex.php?curid=664966 Ciliates  Numerous cilia.  More complex body form than other unicellular eukaryotes.  Defining characteristic: 2 types nuclei.  Mostly heterotrophs – A few photosynthetic endosymbionts. Ciliates  E.g. Paramecium spp.  Slipper-shaped cell covered by pellicle – Pellicle - outer membrane + inner layer of alveoli surrounding bases of cilia – Pellicle contains trichocysts – defensive organelles.  Cilia – coordinated beating – locomotion.  Contractile vacuole – osmoregulation.  Digestive vacuole – endocytosis – digestion. Summary  Many eukaryotes are not animals, plants or fungi – Alveolates  Dinoflagellates  Apicomplexans  Ciliates Next session Many eukaryotes are not animals, plants or fungi  Stramenopiles  Excavates  Rhizarians Title slide image attributions The Three Domains of Life: https://simple.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain_(biology) Phylogentic tree of life: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tree_of_life_(biology) A 2016 (metagenomic) representation of the tree of life: Laura A.
